<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma1
</value></part><part><name>eff</name>=<value> local

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Camera Control

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Sets custom eye accommodation camera aperture (-1 to do it automatically). 

<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> Informative </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> If HDR is enabled (it is enabled by default), when [[setAperture]] <tt>value</tt> is used it also forces [[setApertureNew]] to the following values: [<tt>value</tt>, <tt>value</tt>, <tt>value</tt>, 1]. Execute [[setApertureNew]] after [[setAperture]] to override this default mechanic.</value></part></template>  
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> important </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> The aperture is set to default by the engine at the mission start. If you set it before the mission started it will reset like it never happened. Make sure you set it at the right time (see example 2)</value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''setAperture''' aperture

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> aperture: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Nothing]]
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>[[setAperture]] 0.3;</code>
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>[] [[spawn]] { [[waitUntil]] { [[time]] > 0.1 }; [[setAperture]] 100 };</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[setApertureNew]] [[apertureParams]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dt class="note">[[User:Namikaze|Namikaze]]</dt>
<dd class="note">The aperture value to simulate typical daylight (outdoor) conditions is 50.  The aperture value to simulate typical daylight (indoor) conditions is 30.  Setting the value to less than 20 will result in a very bright scene, suitable for night conditions.  The closer the number is to 0, the more light will be let into the lens, to carry on the aperture metaphor.  Different lighting/weather conditions can change the actual indoor and outdoor aperture values.  Experiment and test to be sure.

<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
